content.webTitle: Team GB to receive celebration fit for heroes, Theresa May says

fields.headline: Team GB to receive celebration fit for heroes, Theresa May says
fields.bodyText: Team GB’s Olympic medallists from the Rio Games will be given “a celebration fit for heroes”, with two victory parades in London and Manchester, Theresa May has announced. “For the past fortnight, the people of the United Kingdom have been filled with pride as we’ve watched our Olympians take victory in so many sports with power, grace and control. In every discipline and at every stage, Team GB have shown the world what we’re made of: determination, dignity and true sportsmanship,” the prime minister said on Friday. May said the government would stage an official victory parade in Manchester later this year, while London mayor Sadiq Khan will organise a parallel celebration on the streets of the capital. No 10 had come under pressure to mark Britain’s record medal haul publicly, amid suggestions that budget constraints meant there would be no official celebration. A Downing Street spokesman said the two events were likely to be held after Britain’s Paralympians return from Rio. The government is keen to keep the Olympic feelgood factor alive as Britain faces the risk of an economic downturn in the wake of the Brexit vote. May said: “The euphoria of London 2012 didn’t end four years ago, and it doesn’t end now – we still have the Paralympic Games to look forward to. It will continue on the streets of Britain as we plan a parade in Manchester, alongside the British Olympic and Paralympic associations. It will be a celebration fit for heroes – and rightly so, because that is exactly what they are.” The prime minister, whose favourite sport is cricket, has been on a walking holiday in Switzerland, but said she had “taken every opportunity” to watch Team GB’s medal-winning performances. May added that a series of “individual moments” would remain in the public’s memories, including cyclist Laura Trott’s gold medal-winning rides and the performance of 16-year-old gymnast Amy Tinkler. Team GB stood second in the medals table on Friday night, with 24 golds and 21 silvers, behind only the USA. The record performance has been partly attributed to a decision by former prime minister Sir John Major to use national lottery money to fund sport, and to a ruthless focus on winnable events. But May said the results also “show just how far talent and hard work can take you”. Khan said: “I am delighted to confirm that there will be an event in London to allow people to celebrate the phenomenal achievements of our Olympians and Paralympians. My team will continue to work with the government and sports chiefs to help develop plans for wonderful celebrations.” Bill Sweeney, chief executive of the British Olympic Association, said: “It is great that Team GB and Paralympics GB athletes will be celebrated for their achievements.” Andy Burnham MP, Labour’s candidate for mayor of Greater Manchester, said: “This is the right decision by the government and I am sure it will be widely-welcomed, not just in Greater Manchester, but across the country as a whole.” Earlier this week, pro-Brexit campaign group Leave.EU tweeted a video message that suggested Team GB’s triumphant performance was proof Britain would be able to thrive outside the EU. Medal-winning cyclist Callum Skinner tweeted in response: “Thanks [for] the support but I wish you wouldn’t use my image to promote your campaign.”
